 Dear Sir -
My acquaintance with your gallery is one of an admirer and visitor, but

frankly as a corresponder [sic] I feel a bit ill at ease, having no knowledge
of your management.

Taos, New Mexico

 For a few days I am returning to Chicago and would appreciate your taking

a look at some of my things in as much as I am a painter. They consist of
watercolors and oils - about fourty [sic] five or fifty in number, which I would
like to show: having

in red Picture attached taken by Mr C 11/10/30
in pencil no - not good show for Arts Club says Miss Carpenter 11/11/30

Mrs. Harold Smith

Wiscasset Maine
October 27th

Dear Miss Roullier -

I am a friend of Katharine Dudley's, & as she is in Paris, I am writing to you direct, to ask if you would be
interested in an exhibition of paintings by a Japanese artist who lives in Mexico & teaches in a school of
open air painting there. I was in Mexico last winter & saw two of his paintings at a show there at the
Modern Gallery in the National Theatre. I liked them so much that I brought up fourteen of them, & the Hackett Galleries,
9 East 57th St, New York are giving him a one man show the last two weeks in November.

I enclose a page from Forma a Mexican magazine, which shows two of his paintings. I have photographs of the other paintings

that I could send you later, but just now they are being used in a magazine article. If you would be interested in giving Mr. Kitagawa
a show at the Arts Club, would you let me know at the above address.

Sincerely,  Susan Smith

Chicago ILL.

Brooklyn       "                "             "

for which I would be eligible.

in different writing'  Non-Res Prof.  member (?)

Mary Ag?is
37 Washington Square, West
New York City
Carol Kreun ocut me a box of this fancy letter paper for Xmas - Very dear of her
but - why ries? name so large?
Dear Attn?

Studying "Art" Certainly has one reward of enjoying  pictures   - for sure - I had such a

good time yesterday, first among the Rousseaus. Nacte? was so crowded there wasn't
air enough; so, marvellous as they were, I had to leave; then at the Peut tower? galleries where
I was the sole admirer of the most delightful, entertaining, ??sically i?yous

element_texts.text: Completed

2
Col. of canvasses by one ? Kadar Bela - a Hungarian -
Have you ever heard of him? They are so fancy and so beautiful, painted and
so colorful -! I wish Fred? Bartlett could see them - He would certainly acquire
some -  The prices I thought very moderate $250-300 - for the larger ones -
85-100 for the smaller - I want to buy one, to ?een aer? for a rainy day -
^I wish you could see them  Why doesn't the Arts Club have the show?
Truly they? all unique - Quite different from anything I've seen - Do talk to
Miss Rouillier - she'll think I'm a nuisance! but am relnt? to miss these joyous things - ho?

 Mary

New York  6 April

My dear Mrs Carpenter,

At this very moment I got a letter from my husband, that he received a letter from you dated
December 10 1930 at my address. this letter must have made a world tour  I regret awfully that I 
didnt see you last winter

Sunday April 26th
The Arts Club
Chicago
I should like information regarding an exhibition at your galleries. Many people in Florida referred
me to Mary Anderson and Mrs. John Alden Carpenter - reproductions of some of my work appeared in
the February 1st issue of "The spur" - a full page portrait of Mrs. Vincent Astor in the March 1st issue

element_texts.text: Completed

of "Spur" - At present there are two small pictures to be hung, by invitation, at the
Chicago Arts Institute's International Competitive Water color show. The technique is water color-
opaque - with gold and silver leaf backgrounds - framed in colored glass and gold and silver mirrored matts.

Please send me any information regarding shows - dates - costs - etc.
Thanking you   I am - most sincerely
Casey Roberts

element_texts.text: Completed

Dear Sir - Miss Magda Heuermann has turned over to us your letter concerning an exhibition of late 16th - early 17th and 18th Century miniatures.
The Arts Club of Chicago would be much interested in holding such an exhibit ^ sometime during the coming year & is well equipped to do so
attractively & successfully. Before offering any suggestions as to dates however, we would have to acertain [sic] the number of items and about what
amount of wall space they would require.

If agreeable to you we would appreciate your writing us directly.
Very truly yours,
Arts C of C   by Alice Rouillier etc
410 N. Michigan Ave

letterhead
CHICAGO SOCIETY OF MINIATURE PAINTERS
Magda Heuermann, Sec'y
520 Fair Oaks Av.  Oak Park, Illinois
handwritten in pencil
I wrote her personally M.H.
Please mail her carbon copy of ^ our letter to Rosenbach Galleries  MH
handwritten in ink
Dear Miss Roullier: -
Kindly read inclosed letter and return to me. Don't you think that either your galleries
or those of the Arts Club would be the best to house an exhibit of that nature?
I personally would  be more than happy if we could succeed in getting an exhibit of such
quality to Chicago. I wrote Mr Dineen, that his letter, I mailed to you, since you are the "boss" of
both galleries.     Sincerely

Magda Heuermann
May 2 - 31

over

THE CHICAGO SOCIETY OF MINIATURE PAINTERS
Lucile Stevenson Dalrymple, Pres
pencil Miss
image of woman in headscarf
June 1st 1931
4704 Drexel Bovl [Blvd?]
My dear Miss Roullier: -

Our society is most interested in having the Sixteenth Century Miniatures

of the Rosenbach Collection shown in Chicago; and would it not seem
apropos to have our Exhibition at the same time?  We invite the American Society

element_texts.text: Completed

and the Philadelphia, California, and Brooklyn societies to show with us and I and sure the added mailing list
of our exhibit will increase the interest in the "old" and "new" with greater "news value".  Mr. Dineen is very
hopeful of securing the most fortunate setting for the old treasures, and would like to have our Society sponsor
the exhibition.   Cordially yours,

Lucille Stevenson Dalrymple

Mrs. E. Blois Du Bois
Telephone:{ Mendenhall Washington Headquarters
WASHINGTON HEADQUARTERS At
Battle of Brandywine
Chadds Ford, Pennsylvania
Antiques  Rare Prints
Tea Room   Terrapin  Terrapin Suppers
To The Chicago Arts Club: __   12: August 1930   File 9/20/30
Dear Sirs: __

I have for sale the entire Bliss Collection of Alphonse underlined red; red question mark Legros - with the

exception of twenty unimportant prints sold by Mr. Bliss in London several years ago.  I have been told that you might
be interested in such a collection and would be glad to furnish you with further information if you are interested.
Very sincerely yours   Helen H. du Bois
pu? Flo?

Beverly (Beverly) Mass.

Very sincerely yours    Frederic Clay Bartlett

element_texts.text: Completed

100, Rue D'Assas, VI
Tel. Littre 91-90
10.6 1931
Dear Miss Fariss?

I am sorry to derange again whiter  [sic: with?] another letter but I hope I am certain iL [it] is going to be the last one containing complaints, and

my Lulur? or Later? letter will be only of gratitude and pleasant things.   Well, When M-me Prax? (my wife) received her pictures she found
six frames completely deteriorated and two glaces of the paintings on paper broken  She made the working man who opened the cases
contate? the damage: and The General transport firm promised me to day to write to the New York firm Galager and Saber

about the same things. Please write to them also. M-me Prax? wants that a 100 francs per frame
and 30 fr per glass should be payed to her - which is not very expensive - you will agree.

I hope iL [it] will not Disturb you doing it.  Whith [sic] all our greetings

yours sincerely   O. ZA K,,?  could be Val Prax
in pencil
6/26/31  Notified Stanley of Klee Rogers - of 660 fr damage
Zadkine 660 francs
26.40  about $25 00

100, Rue D'Assas, Paris VI
Tel. Danton 91-90
the 16 of March 1932
Dear Miss Faris

I am very sorry for having neglected to answer you and acknowledge the reception of the check for 25

dollars. Please excuse me. the check was indeed recorded some months ago and cashed by ?ied..ly
whith [sic: with] all my excuses     yours sincerely   Valentine Prax.

element_texts.text: Completed

typed in French, with English penciled between each line. Transcribing the French, then the English
French
fusion n'exclut pas la premeditation, ou l'art n'est pas
l'ennemi de la generosite. Nouse ressentons surtout de la
curiosite pour les formes qui, tout en appartenant en propre
a notre epoque, rappellent les gestes primordiaux, les plus
eternals. Notre style, nous entendons le greffer non sur celui
qu'on nous ressasse comme pouvant etre le seul classique,
par definition, mais sur celui d'une tradition moins abimee, 
moins usee.
English
premeditation, where art is not
the enemy of generosity - We feel again especially
curiosity for the formes which, although belonging
to our own epoch, recall the primitive
the eternal. Our style, we intend to graft it not on
that which has been (ressasse) as having been
the only classic, by definition, but on that of a tradition less abysmal
less used.
in pencil  Andre de Ridder  
"Editions des Chroniques du Jour"
Paris, 1929

element_texts.text: Completed

100 Rue D'Assas VI
Tel. Littre 91-90
6.12.30
Dear Miss Roullier

I am sending you out this afternoon the catalogue list and price list together whith [sic] this letter, and

another packet whith [sic] the prefaces of the Putnam and extractions of many articles monographs and
a biographical notice - a real volume of notices, enough to make and print a little book. It would be nice
if you could find something better than a mere catalogue, for it could be sold and would recover the expenses.
But, it is only an idea, and you know better what you

Caption-Abstract: Use the link to the finding aid for a fuller description of collection contents that explains the use of the name and subject terms appearing in this catalog record.
Use the link to the finding aid for a fuller description of collection contents that explains the use of the name and subject terms appearing in this catalog record.
Use the link to the finding aid for a fuller description of collection contents that explains the use of the name and subject terms appearing in this catalog record.

element_texts.text: Completed

ought to do.
I am also sending you together whith [sic] the sculptures (which will sail the eleventh, having been
arrived by Chenne? ) 40 copies of my big monograph the price of it is  120 f. or 4 dollars
and the coito? gives to the club 30% of commision?. The non sold in pencil: unsold
must be sent back whith [sic] the sculpture. It was a surprise to lern [sic] that the show is advanced.
I hope that every thing arives [sic] in time.
Valentine sends you her love and miself [sic] all my gratitude

your sincerely    O. ZAdkin

element_texts.text: Completed

Philadelphia, PA.
December 23rd
The Arts Club of Chicago.

Dear Miss Secretary:
 I am writing you in reference to our shipment on Dec. 20th of eight cases of art subjects from the

La France Industries for your coming exhibit.

I had your letter on the shipping instructions regarding express and special contract covering

shipments in excess of $550.  I regret to say that that the contract was made out for only six hundred
dollars, instead of thirty-six hundred  dollars, which should have been the declared value. 

 This was a serious error on my part and trust that

the cases will arrive safely

Caption-Abstract: Use the link to the finding aid for a fuller description of collection contents that explains the use of the name and subject terms appearing in this catalog record.

element_texts.text: Completed

Philadelphia, PA.

as it would mean my discharge should anything happen to them in transit as they are

part of Mr. Davis's personal collection.

I will greatly appreciate it if when the subjects are to be returned you will advise the one

in charge as to the real valuation being $3600. [circled] so that the error I made will not
be repeated.   Thanking you  I am,

Respectfully yours,
Charles Johnson,
Assistant Shipper
La France Industries
 Frankford, Phila.

element_texts.text: Completed

No. 203
Department of Printed Books
British Museum
London, W.C.
20th Jan 1931

Sir,
I beg to acknowledge with thanks the receipt of
The Arts Club of Chicago Catalogue of an
Exhibition of Sculpture by Ossib Zadkine.
which you have been so good as to present to the

Trustees of the British Museum.

 I am,  Sir,
Your obedient Servant.
  W.A. Marsden     Keeper

The Secretary.
The Arts Club of Chicago,

Chicago, ILL  U.S.A.

element_texts.text: Completed

100 Rue D'Assas VI
Tel. Littre 91-90
the 15.3.1931.
Dear Miss Jarvis

We just receaved [sic] (Mame Prax and Mr Zadkins) your registered letter and the two checks

it contained. Thank you very much. I wrote to Miss Alice Roullier, where I expressed my - crossed out our
desire to see our work back in Paris underlined if, of course, nothing is definately [sic] aranged [sic] before the end of
April /underline as the season after that month is at an end and every body is gone travelling. Please discuss this matter
whith [sic] Miss Alice Roullier and do what you will decide the best. for we have utter confidence in you both.

Sincerely yours O. Zadkine

element_texts.text: Completed

100 Rue D'Assas VI
Tel. Littre 91-90
the 9th Juli[?] 1931
Dear Miss Jarvis

You will receive this letter very much later, after having received our telegram announcing you that

we have receaved [sic] our paintings and sculptures.  But when we counted up the amount of my money cafles?
we discovered that three are lacking. Please if possible make some inquiries so that they would be discovered
and if sold, the money should be sent to the publisher Mr St Lazaro, 100 rue d'Assas, Paris 6.

element_texts.text: Completed

Please give all my best wishes to Miss Alice Roullier and receave? our [[thanking?]
for all your so kind intellious? during our exhibition

 O. Zadkine

P.S.  It is possible that the three copies have been sold in Philadelphia, perhaps

   O.Z.
